title: What are the downsides of filing for personal bankruptcy, would that impact obtaining visitor visas in future?
question: Hello, a friend is interested in visiting the US at a future date but due to her current financial troubles, she is forced to file for personal bankruptcy, her main concern is will this appear on her record when the embassy does a background check on her and could this contribute to having her visitor visa application rejected? since being bankrupt could be read as "bad moral character".
answers:
Who may be a debtor under Chapter 7

11 U.S. Code § 109.(a)Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, only a person that resides or has a domicile, a place of business, or property in the United States, or a municipality, may be a debtor under this title.

You may want to talk with an attorney about if you have to have a residence to file, or if it enough to have property in the U.S.
Bankruptcy is not evidence of bad moral character. It's evidence of getting stuck in a bad financial situation. It is also guaranteed by the Constitution.

Bankruptcy would appear on ones credit report, but this is not a suggestion of bad moral character. Also, I have not heard of bankruptcy being an impediment to obtaining a visa. If anything, bankruptcy shows the individual is trying to take care of their debts.

Many people are already bankruptcy before they even file bankruptcy, so the filing of bankruptcy is more of a legal process to eliminate ones debts and provide immediate relief.

I hope this helps.

I know of no barriers for VISAs, immigration or citizenship if one files bankruptcy.
However, one needs to be a resident of the USA to file bankruptcy, not just a visitor.
Joseph Wrobel
